text.text_translated: In the 1950s, companies that grew and sold bananas in Central America were facing the death of their most profitable product, the Gros Michel banana, which was also known as Big Mike. And now, the same problem is happening again to the Cavendish, which is the banana that came after Big Mike. The Gros Michel banana plant dominated the plantations in Central America because its fruit was easy to transport, had thick skin, and tasted sweet. United Fruit, which was the main company growing and selling bananas in South America at that time, produced a very large number of bananas in the most efficient way possible. They did this by taking new plants from the stems of existing plants instead of growing them from seeds, and they planted them very close together in the fields.
